Pygame Zero Cheat Sheet

Made by Copilot from sample Python files.

1. Basic Setup

Importing Pygame Zero

import pgzrun

Setting Screen Dimensions and Title

# Set the size of the screen and the Title
WIDTH = 800
HEIGHT = 600
TITLE = "My Awesome Game"

Pygame Zero uses these global constants to set up the game window.

Defining Colors (RGB Tuples)

# Colours (RGB) - Constants
WHITE = (255, 255, 255)
RED = (180, 0, 0)
BLUE = (0, 0, 255)
GREEN = (0, 170, 0)
YELLOW = (255, 255, 0)
BGCOLOUR = (0, 0, 160) # Example background color

Starting the Game

pgzrun.go()

This line must be at the end of your script to start the Pygame Zero game loop.

2. Game Loop Functions

draw()

def draw():
    # This function draws everything on the screen
    screen.clear() # Clears the previous frame (optional, screen.fill also clears)
    screen.fill(BGCOLOUR) # Set the background color

    # Draw your game objects here
    # Example: player.draw()
    # Example: screen.draw.text("Score: " + str(score), (10, 10), color=WHITE)

This function runs over and over to draw everything on the screen.

update()

def update():
    # This function updates the game state
    # Move objects, check for collisions, handle game logic, etc.
    # Example: player.x += 5
    pass

This function runs over and over (usually 60 times a second) to update your game's logic.

3. Drawing Primitives

To draw things, use the screen.draw object inside the draw() function.

Filling the Screen

screen.fill(RED) # Fills the entire screen with the color RED

Drawing a Circle

screen.draw.circle((x_center, y_center), radius, COLOR)
# Example:
screen.draw.circle((400, 300), 30, WHITE)

Drawing a Filled Rectangle

screen.draw.filled_rect(Rect(left, top, width, height), COLOR)
# Example:
screen.draw.filled_rect(Rect(0, 500, 800, 100), BLUE)

Note: Rect is an object for a rectangle. You can also make it with Rect((left, top), (width, height)).

Drawing a Line

screen.draw.line((start_x, start_y), (end_x, end_y), COLOR)
# Example:
screen.draw.line((0, 0), (800, 600), YELLOW)

Drawing Text

screen.draw.text("Your text here", (x_pos, y_pos), color=COLOR, fontsize=SIZE)
# Example:
screen.draw.text("Hello, World!", (700, 550), color=WHITE, fontsize=40)

4. Actors

Actors are game objects. They have an image, a position, and other details.

Creating an Actor

Put actor images in an 'images' folder.

# player = Actor('image_file_name_without_extension', (initial_x, initial_y))
# Example:
player = Actor('heath', (WIDTH // 2, HEIGHT // 2))
ghost = Actor('ghost', (100, HEIGHT // 2))

Drawing an Actor

Do this in the draw() function.

player.draw()
ghost.draw()

Moving an Actor

Usually, you do this in the update() function.

# Change x and y attributes
player.x = player.x - 5  # Move left
player.y += 5            # Move down

# Example:
ghost.x += 1 # Move ghost 1px to the right each frame

Actor Position Attributes

Actors have different ways to get or set their position:

  • actor.x, actor.y: Center points
  • actor.pos: Tuple (x, y) for center
  • actor.left, actor.right, actor.top, actor.bottom: Edge points
  • actor.center: Tuple (x, y) for center (same as pos)
  • actor.width, actor.height: Size of the actor's image
# Example: Keep actor on screen
if player.left < 0:
    player.left = 0
elif player.right > WIDTH:
    player.right = WIDTH

Changing Actor Image

actor.image = 'new_image_name' # Without extension
# Example (from 4_sample.py, changing cross to tick):
# if heath.colliderect(cross):
#     cross.image = 'tick'
# else:
#     cross.image = 'cross'

5. Input Handling

Keyboard Input (Polling in update())

def update():
    if keyboard.left:  # True if left arrow key is currently pressed
        player.x -= 5
    if keyboard.right:
        player.x += 5
    if keyboard.up:
        player.y -= 5
    if keyboard.down:
        player.y += 5
    if keyboard.space: # True if spacebar is pressed
        # Do something
        pass

Use keyboard.KEY_NAME (like keyboard.a or keyboard.k_1) for other keys.

Keyboard Input (Event-based)

def on_key_down(key):
    # This function is called once when a key is pressed down
    # 'key' is a Key object
    if key == keys.LEFT:
        print("Left key pressed")
    # Example from 5_sample.py (for game reset):
    # if game_state == 'GAME_OVER':
    #     if key == keys.SPACE:
    #         reset_game()

def on_key_up(key):
    # This function is called once when a key is released
    if key == keys.RIGHT:
        print("Right key released")

Mouse Input (Event-based)

def on_mouse_down(pos):
    # 'pos' is a tuple (x, y) of the mouse click position
    # Example:
    cross.pos = pos # Move an actor to the click position

    # Check collision with an actor at mouse position
    if heath.collidepoint(pos): # or heath.collidepoint(pos[0], pos[1])
        print("Clicked on Heath!")
    
    # Example from 4_sample.py:
    # if heath.colliderect(cross): # Assuming cross is moved to pos
    #     score += 1
    #     cross.image = 'tick'
    # else:
    #     score -= 1
    #     cross.image = 'cross'

Other mouse events: on_mouse_up(pos), on_mouse_move(pos, rel, buttons).

6. Collision Detection

Actor vs Actor Collision (colliderect())

Checks if two actors' boxes overlap.

# In update() function
if player.colliderect(enemy_actor):
    # Collision occurred!
    print("Collision!")
    # Example: Reposition coin after collision
    # coin.x, coin.y = (random.randint(0, WIDTH), random.randint(0, HEIGHT))

# Example from 5_sample.py (checking against a list of enemies):
# for enemy in enemies:
#     if heath.colliderect(enemy):
#         game_state = 'GAME_OVER'
#         sounds.death.play() # Play a sound
#         break

Actor vs Point Collision (collidepoint())

Checks if a point is inside an actor's box.

# In on_mouse_down(pos) or similar
if actor.collidepoint(pos): # pos is (x, y) tuple
    print("Point is inside actor")
# Or:
# if actor.collidepoint(x_coordinate, y_coordinate):
#    print("Point is inside actor")

7. Random Numbers

Importing random

import random

Random Integer

random_x = random.randint(min_val, max_val)
# Example:
coin.x = random.randint(0, WIDTH)

Random Choice from a List

# Example from 5_sample.py for enemy direction:
# FIRE_SPEED = 3
# new_fire.direction = random.choice([(0, FIRE_SPEED), 
#                                     (0, -FIRE_SPEED), 
#                                     (FIRE_SPEED, 0), 
#                                     (-FIRE_SPEED, 0), 
#                                     (FIRE_SPEED, FIRE_SPEED)])

8. Lists for Multiple Objects

Good for handling many similar things, like enemies or bullets.

Creating and Populating a List of Actors

enemies = [] # Initialize an empty list

# Create an actor and add it
fire_1 = Actor('fire', (random.randint(0, WIDTH), 300))
# You can add custom attributes to actors:
# fire_1.direction = (0, FIRE_SPEED) 
enemies.append(fire_1)

# Dynamically add more enemies (e.g., in update())
# new_fire = Actor('fire', (random.randint(0, WIDTH), random.randint(0, HEIGHT)))
# enemies.append(new_fire)

Iterating Through a List (in update() and draw())

# In update() for logic (e.g., movement, collision)
def update():
    for enemy in enemies:
        enemy.y += 1 # Move enemy down
        # Check collision, etc.

# In draw() to draw all objects in the list
def draw():
    screen.fill(BGCOLOUR)
    for enemy in enemies:
        enemy.draw()
    player.draw() # Draw other objects

9. Game State Management

Use variables to manage different parts of your game (like 'playing', 'game over', or 'menu').

# Generated by Copilot
game_state = 'PLAYING' # Can be 'MENU', 'GAME_OVER', etc.

def update():
    global game_state
    if game_state == 'PLAYING':
        # Normal game logic
        # if player_collides_with_hazard:
        #     game_state = 'GAME_OVER'
        pass
    elif game_state == 'GAME_OVER':
        # Logic for game over screen
        # if keyboard.space:
        #     reset_game() # Function to reset variables
        pass # Added pass for syntactical correctness if content is empty

def draw():
    screen.clear()
    if game_state == 'PLAYING':
        # Draw playing state
        # player.draw()
        # for enemy in enemies:
        #     enemy.draw()
        pass
    elif game_state == 'GAME_OVER':
        # Draw game over screen
        screen.draw.text('GAME OVER', center=(WIDTH/2, HEIGHT/2 - 30), fontsize=60, color=RED)
        screen.draw.text('Press SPACE to play again', center=(WIDTH/2, HEIGHT/2 + 50), fontsize=30)

10. Sounds

Put sound files (WAV or OGG) in a 'sounds' folder.

Loading a Sound

# Sounds are automatically loaded if you create a 'sounds' folder
# and place your .wav or .ogg files there.
# The sound object is named after the file (without extension).
# e.g., sounds/ding.wav  becomes sounds.ding

Playing a Sound

sounds.ding.play() # Plays the 'ding.wav' sound effect
# Example from 5_sample.py:
# if heath.colliderect(coin):
#     sounds.ding.play()
#     score += 1
#     # ... reposition coin ...
# elif heath.colliderect(enemy):
#     sounds.death.play()
#     game_state = 'GAME_OVER'

11. Playing Background Music

Put music files (MP3 or OGG) in a 'music' folder.

Pygame Zero automatically plays music/background.mp3 (or .ogg) if it's there. For more control, use the music object.

Controlling Music

To play a specific music file (e.g., mymusic.mp3 in the 'music' folder):

music.play('mymusic') # Starts playing 'music/mymusic.mp3'

To play it repeatedly (looping):

music.play_once('another_track') # Plays once, then stops
music.queue('track_for_later') # Adds to the end of the current playlist

Other useful music functions:

  • music.pause(): Pauses the music.
  • music.unpause(): Resumes paused music.
  • music.stop(): Stops music and clears the list.
  • music.fadeout(seconds): Fades out music over some seconds, then stops.
  • music.is_playing(): Returns True if music is playing.
  • music.set_volume(volume): Sets volume (0.0 to 1.0). Default is 1.0.
  • music.get_volume(): Gets current volume.

Example from 5_sample.py (though it uses automatic playback):

# In 5_sample.py, 'music/bg-music.mp3' would play automatically if named 'background.mp3'.
# To control it manually, you might do:
# At the start of the game:
# music.play('bg-music')
# music.set_volume(0.3) # Set volume to 30%

# When game over:
# if game_state == 'GAME_OVER':
#     music.fadeout(1) # Fade out over 1 second

12. Timers (Scheduled Functions)

Pygame Zero can run a function after a set time.

Scheduling a Function

def my_delayed_function():
    print("This appears after 2 seconds!")

# Schedule my_delayed_function to be called after 2.0 seconds
clock.schedule_unique(my_delayed_function, 2.0)

schedule_unique makes sure a timed function runs only once, even if you schedule it many times quickly. It cancels old schedules for that function and uses the new one. This helps stop the same timed event from happening too many times.

Other scheduling options:

  • clock.schedule(function, delay): Schedules the function. If called again, it schedules another one.
  • clock.schedule_interval(function, interval): Calls the function over and over at the set interval.
  • clock.unschedule(function): Removes all scheduled calls for this function.
# Example: Spawning an enemy every 3 seconds
# def spawn_enemy():
#     new_enemy = Actor('enemy_image', (random.randint(0, WIDTH), 0))
#     enemies.append(new_enemy)
#
# clock.schedule_interval(spawn_enemy, 3.0)
